bboxes.raw_text:
ALBANY, Ga. An interra-
cial group of nine Cuba bound
"peace marchers" was convicted
Of illegal parading through this
South Georgia city.


City Judge a. N. burden Or
dered three Negroes and six
whites to pay STOP each or spend
IS days in Jail.


Five other marchers, who re-
fused TO leave their cells below
the courtroom, we're cited for
contempt of court and sentenced
to seven days each.


They we're arrested Dec. %
on charges of deviating from a
prescribed parade route, dis
obeying police order and dis
orderly conduct.

JENNINGS, Mo, A special
police guard outside the home
OF a woman editor who received
a telephoned threat she had only
"a hours to live.


Mrs. Jean Gardner, mother Of
four and publisher Of the weekly
Jennings News In this racially
troubled St. Louis suburg, said
a man phoned her home.


1t was the fifth threat by tele-
phone Mrs. Gardner had received
in 3O-hour period, but the first
that threatened her life. Two
other calls threatened damage to
her newspaper shop.


The calls came after this
weeks Issue of the News was
published with a headline, ERA
cial Problem Gives Jennings a
Black Eye


The story blamed teen-age
hoodlumism for the firecrack-
ers and window smashing which
plagued Negro family.

LOS ANGELES The legal
profession is "the worst inte-
grated and worst segregated
group in our society, said U. S.
Secretary of Labor Willard
Writ. He spoke at the recent
convention of the Association of
American Law Schools in Los
Angeles.


Not more than 35 of the nation S
principal law firms are inte-
grated, he charged.


Writ said further that a Negro
has almost no chance to be ad-
mitted to major law firm.


The barriers that he encount-
ers in trying to get In is ex-
cceded only by "that of. female
and poorly groomed applicants"

WRIT SAYS


LAW PROFESSION
IS MOST BIASED

WASHINGTON The US. Su-
preme Court struck down a
Louisiana law requiring the race
of candidates for all state cleo
tive offices.


The decision wa handed down on
an appeal by two Negroes who
we're unsucces sful candidates for
nomination on the school board of
East Baton Rouge parish in a
Democratic primary on July %,
1862.


Deputy H. Anderson and Acie
J. Bolton, the two Negroes said
the RECRUITMENT was unconstitu-
tional and made racial discrimi-
nation possible.


Justice Clark rendering the
unanimous decision said a racial
label on candidate furnishes a
vehicle to arouse prejudices.

SUPREME COURT


STRIKES DOWN RACE
TAG ON CANDIDATES

The Southminster Presbyer-
ian Church, 1923 l.. Broadway,
will present "The Battle Of the
Choirs" on Sun. Jan. 10 3 pm.


Several Valley choirs will ap-
pear. This program launches the
cclebrationn of the tenth ami
versary of the church.


Programs will aid financing
in a new building project, which
will consist of youth center,
fellowship hall for public use
and Sunday School classrooms.


The public is invited to attend.
